Hi all,
Having the book and seeing all the text with diagrams
pointing to marks on a menuki, makes me almost crazy
in not being able to read what they are saying.  Of
course, not crazy enough to actually learn japanese
like some you do.  

FYI for those that want to know about the book some
more, the first section is all pics of the 17
generations work.  then it gets into text what I
assume is detailing a bit about each generation and
how you can tell it was them. Has diagrams and you can
tell some things like one generation used a rounded
edge etc,.  I would push for a translation more if I
really was collecting Goto work.  But since I don't
collect in that range usually ($$$$$$), there are so
many other books I want info on.  Of course I did
acquire 1 nice Goto mantis piece recently (most likely
Kaga Goto). Haven't seen a Mantis Goto menuki yet. 
Some beautiful work though, amazing detail.  

Then of course there are all the side groups who
worked in similiar style and at times did more
interesting work as the Goto school was very rigid in
what they did (ok I read that in one of those books
out there).  Does anyone know of any articles on Kaga
goto?  I know there is the Kaga takain, but at around
$700- 800, I'm not in the market for it.  Gotta go the
"hidden fortress" is on IFC- great samurai movie.

Ken aka "the mantis dude"

>   On 5/27/06, Barry Thomas <warlord@...>
> wrote:
>   >
>   > Blokes,
>   >
>   > The story I remember is that menuki are
> vestigial ornaments from pre-Heian
>   > times
>   > when the tsuka was fixed to the nakago with a
> rivet that was not
>   > removable.  The
>   > heads of the rivet were decorated and eventually
> became the menuki we know
>   > today.  What I did not know until these emails
> is that some menuki have
>   > "interlocking pins" to become mekugi.  Sure,
> I've seen these on cheap
>   > Meiji
>   > pieces, especially tanto, but didn't know early
> Goto menuki had the same
>   > feature.  We can clearly see that as the Nihonto
> developed from earliest
>   > times
>   > the disadvantage of a fixed rivet became
> evident, but the early menuki
>   > discussed
>   > appear to have still functioned as a mekugi,
> only later becoming separate
>   > with a
>   > bamboo mekugi, or mekugi of other material
> (iron??).  I also remember that
>   > in
>   > the Momoyama period a single menuki was used,
> accounting for some of the
>   > "orphans" we see.  Looking back over my
> collecting career I think I once
>   > had a
>   > single (i.e., never a pair) shakudo menuki of a
> pomegranate.  It was of
>   > that
>   > really dark black shakudo.  Sometimes knowledge
> comes too late to save us
>   > from
>   > ourselves!!!
>   >
>   > Ken, I do have somewhere a late 19th century
> English treatise on the Goto
>   > mainline (Shirobei 17 generations) with photos,
> but it doesn't go into the
>   > "secret marks"...  Does anyone know the title of
> the Japanese one that Ken
>   > mentions??
>   >
>   > Regards,
>   >
>   > Barry Thomas.
